title: The Real Reason Tom Sosnoff Left TastyLive
text: I think a lot of us when we heard that you're leaving Tasty Live obviously most people are completely shocked and it's because you've obviously built your whole life around markets doing that whole thing. I think sometimes people forget that your serial entrepreneur did the whole think or swim thing, then made a jump, did something else and this is kind of part of your broader MMO, but I think a lot of us got rolled into a fall sense of security and the news drops. So talk to us about that. What led to the switch? And can you explain a little bit about the timing? Why then? Sure, because so I am definitely an entrepreneur. I'm a little bit of a cycle in that sense. For the last 44 years I have worked essentially for myself. I have even what I've killed basically. The only two times I've ever received a paycheck in 44 years where, well, right when I got a college I had a job for about six months, but that doesn't count. When we got bought out by TD Ameritrade and then when we got bought out by IG, only times I've ever received a paycheck. It simply checks though. Yeah, but not something that I'm used to or whatever, it doesn't. It didn't register with me. At TD, I didn't cash a check for two years until they basically said, you've got to cash these checks and they're not going to be good

At TD, I didn't cash a check for two years until they basically said, you've got to cash these checks and they're not going to be good anymore. And IG, I cash a check, but I had no idea what they paid me. I got it even no. I didn't even know. I didn't even know. I swear to God, I don't know. So I've been pretty much on my own. I still consider it and you know, always being on my own. And after you get bought out, you lose control. And it's kind of a weird thing. When we got bought out the first time by TD, I stayed on for two years because I just, you know, I was, I had, I had agreed to stay on for three years, but I was very close to the CEO Fred Tomzack at the time. And after two years, I went to him and said, you know, Fred, am I ever going to be the CEO of TD Ameritrade? And he looked at me and he said, not, not over my dead body. And so we laughed about it and I said, listen, you know, I got to do something else. And because I, I'm getting older, I got to, you know, I got to build some stuff.
